results.headline: A Young Viagra Salesman Sees Lust Turn Into Love
results.summary_short: Jake Gyllenhaal and Anne Hathaway star in a romantic comedy set in the dawning of the age of Viagra.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Love and Other Drugs

results.headline: From Tooth Fairy to High-Speed Human Tank
results.summary_short: For Dwayne Johnson, “Faster” is a total about-face after the family-friendly baby food of “The Tooth Fairy.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Faster

results.headline: Small-Town Girl Trades Her Naïveté for Lingerie
results.summary_short: In “Burlesque,” Christina Aguilera walks into Cher’s Los Angeles club, one of those atmospheric holes in the wall where dreams turn into realities.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Burlesque

results.headline: Wanderer in Bewitching, Fractious Land
results.summary_short: The Sri Lankan filmmaker Vimukthi Jayasundara’s vivid and oblique “Between Two Worlds” drops a man from the sky and trusts we will follow him.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Between Two Worlds

results.headline: Tensions Between Companionship and Solitude
results.summary_short: Lotte Verbeek and Stephen Rea star in Urszula Antoniak’s maddeningly enigmatic and sensuous “Nothing Personal.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nothing Personal

results.headline: Hanging on for a Dear Way of Life
results.summary_short: In Claire Denis’s “White Material,” Isabelle Huppert plays a coffee farmer surrounded by the chaos and conflicts of postcolonial Africa.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of White Material

results.headline: Time for Young Wizards to Put Away Childish Things
results.summary_short: There is an especially somber and scary coloration to this installment, as Harry Potter faces a perilous grown-up world.
results.display_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1

results.headline: Food, Family and Follies
results.summary_short: In “Today’s Special,” directed by David Kaplan, Aasif Mandvi plays an Indian sous chef in Manhattan who reconnects with his roots.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Today's Special

results.headline: Passion at the Piano
results.summary_short: Adria Petty’s “Regina Spektor: Live in London” is pretty much just that: a performance by Ms. Spektor at the Hammersmith Apollo at the end of 2009.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Regina Spektor: Live in London

results.headline: An Everyman’s Guide to Engineering a Jail Break
results.summary_short: “The Next Three Days,” a thriller written and directed by Paul Haggis, is in many respects old-fashioned, but is also a kind of cinematic “Illegal Activity for Dummies.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Next Three Days

results.headline: ’60s Sweatshop Girls Fighting Ford
results.summary_short: “Made in Dagenham” is a feminist fairy tale based on actual events whose heroine, a composite of real-life women, leads Ford workers in the battle for equal pay.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Made in Dagenham

results.headline: Out of the Dark Shadows, Arty Toil and Trouble
results.summary_short: Jim Sturgess plays a painfully shy young man in “Heartless,” Philip Ridley’s art-house-aspiring horror movie, set in East London.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Heartless

results.headline: Sport and Grim Reality
results.summary_short: Two documentaries by Bob Ray examine Austin, Tex., culture, one through a roller-derby league, the other through a local character named Chad Holt.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Total Badass

results.headline: Naked Lusts and Natural Painkillers: Portrait of a Literary Outlaw
results.summary_short: “A Man Within” is a sort of genealogy of hip that connects William S. Burroughs with many currents of America’s outlaw cultural tradition.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of William Burroughs: A Man Within

results.headline: For Dinner Tonight: Los Angeles
results.summary_short: In “Skyline,” a pack of hungry space aliens drops in on Southern California for a bite.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Skyline

results.headline: Global Warming and Common Sense
results.summary_short: Ondi Timoner’s documentary about the Danish economist Bjorn Lomborg, who earned the ire of the green movement.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cool It

results.headline: A New Look at the Horrors in Rwanda
results.summary_short: “Shake Hands With the Devil,” directed by Roger Spottiswoode, is a dramatization of the 1994 slaughter in Rwanda.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shake Hands with the Devil

results.headline: The Life of a Contract Killer
results.summary_short: If the aim of “The Magician” is to prove that the life of the average hit man is as grindingly tedious as that of the average road sweeper, then mission accomplished.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Magician

results.headline: The Logistician of the Holocaust
results.summary_short: “Eichmann” claims the moral high ground of being based not just on a true story but on “official Israeli interrogation manuscripts.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Eichmann

results.headline: I Think I Can: Trying to Stop a Crazy Train Hurtling to Disaster
results.summary_short: In “Unstoppable,” Denzel Washington and Chris Pine try to stop a runaway train carrying hazardous cargo.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Unstoppable
